node.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Pfizerâ€™s Booster and Omicron.
node.alt: A vaccination clinic in San Antonio, Tex., in September.
node.description: The booster protects, and two shots may not be enough.
node.content: ["Pfizer and BioNTech said Wednesday that two doses of their Covid vaccine \u201cmay not be sufficient to protect against infection\u201d by the new Omicron variant, but lab tests suggested that three doses offered significant protection.", "The companies said that blood tests from people who received only two doses found much lower antibody levels against Omicron compared with an earlier version of the virus.", "Blood samples obtained from people one month after a booster shot showed neutralizing antibodies against Omicron, comparable to the levels of antibodies against a previous version of the virus after two doses, the companies said.", "Big takeaway: These experiments, done with blood samples in the lab, cannot determine for sure how the vaccines will perform in the real world. But the results seem to underscore the importance of booster shots.", "What\u2019s next: Pfizer\u2019s chairman said the company started developing a version of its vaccine targeting Omicron last month, and that it could be produced within 95 days. Moderna is on a similar path.", "Here are the latest updates and maps of the pandemic.", "In other developments:", "Angela Merkel handed over the chancellery to Olaf Scholz, beginning a new chapter for Europe\u2019s largest democracy.", "Scholz will lead the first center-left government in 16 years and will be in the difficult spot of trying to live up to the high expectations set by Merkel.", "Several crises demand his immediate attention, chief among them the coronavirus pandemic and a possible Russian military invasion of Ukraine. Scholz is also working to win back a working-class base.", "End of an era: Under Merkel, Germany became Europe\u2019s leading power for the first time in modern history. We looked at Merkel\u2019s tenure in photos.", "Swearing-in: Scholz omitted the \u201cso help me God\u201d of the traditional oath. The transition was harmonious, with kind words from Merkel and Scholz to each other. In her farewell remarks, Merkel called the chancellorship \u201cone of the most beautiful duties there are.\u201d", "Firsts: Turkish people are Germany\u2019s largest immigrant group. Germany elected its first Turkish-German minister. Also, Scholz\u2019s incoming cabinet will have more women than ever before. Half, to be exact.", "Britain, Australia and Canada were among the latest countries to join the U.S. in pulling their top officials from the 2022 Beijing Olympics. Their athletes will still be allowed to compete.", "The move allows the countries to register their disapproval of China over its human rights abuses. The nations hope to send a message to China about the internment of Uyghur Muslims in Xinjiang and other issues of concern.", "Iain Duncan Smith, a member of Prime Minister Boris Johnson\u2019s Conservative Party, said Johnson\u2019s move was \u201cnot at all strong enough.\u201d", "China\u2019s response: The word \u201cboycott\u201d appeared to have been banned in online searches. A spokesman for the Chinese embassy said, \u201cThe Beijing Winter Olympics is a gathering of Olympic athletes and winter sports lovers across the world, not a tool of political manipulation for any country.\u201d", "Analysis: Our columnist writes that the diplomatic boycotts are a start, but they do not go far enough. Corporations sponsoring the events should also act, he writes.", "Olympics viewing guide: Speedskating, curling and monobob: Here\u2019s a look at every sport that will be contested at the 2022 Winter Games.", "The idea that Yoko Ono doomed the Beatles has long been criticized. Amanda Hess, a critic at large for The Times, writes that in \u201cThe Beatles: Get Back,\u201d a new eight-hour documentary, Ono\u2019s presence is a sort of artistic performance in itself. \u201cOno simply never leaves,\u201d Hess writes. \u201cShe refuses to decamp to the sidelines, but she also resists acting out stereotypes.\u201d", "Lives Lived: Hyun Sook Han was 12 when she fled her home during the Korean War. She dedicated her life to an adoption program for Korean orphans. Han died at 83.", "We rounded up 21 things that happened for the first time this year \u2014 some are surprising trends, others are serious events. Here\u2019s an excerpt, or see the full list.", "1. An African woman led the World Trade Organization.", "2. A purely digital artwork sold at auction for millions.", "3. A human brain was wirelessly connected to a computer via a transmitter device.", "4. Mexico elected its first transgender lawmakers.", "5. The world\u2019s first 3-D-printed school opened in Malawi.", "6. El Salvador became the first country to make Bitcoin a national currency.", "7. NASA\u2019s Perseverance rover made oxygen on Mars.", "8. National Geographic cartographers recognized the Southern Ocean as the world\u2019s fifth ocean.", "9. SpaceX launched the first all-civilian crew into space.", "10. Sales of zero-emission vehicles surpassed diesel sales in Europe.", "Endlessly adaptable, this is one version of aloo anday, a Pakistani dish of spicy scrambled eggs and potatoes.", "Five minutes that will make you love the organ. ", "Here\u2019s how to use your phone\u2019s privacy protection tools.", "Here\u2019s today\u2019s Mini Crossword, and a clue: Speaking platform (four letters).", "And here is today\u2019s Spelling Bee.", "You can find all our puzzles here.", "That\u2019s it for today\u2019s briefing. See you next time. \u2014 Melina", "P.S. The Times is debuting an iPhone audio app for podcasts and more.", "The latest episode of \u201cThe Daily\u201d is about Ukraine.", "You can reach Melina and the team at briefing@nytimes.com."]
